+ There's definitely something special about Sang-Froid: Tales of Werewolves's combination of action and strategy. Even if sometimes you'll disagree with some of the design decisions, it's unique setting and compelling gameplay will make every victory satisfying.
- Performance is bad. It never became terrible or unplayable, but the almost one minute loading screen and the overall low framerate is as much a mistery for high end PC owners as it is a hindrance to the gameplay.

Overall, a very unique and interesting game that makes me excited for a bigger, better second volume. There's a clunky feel to it that I find somewhat charming, but it's completely understandable that peope get put off by it. The song is pretty good too, and damn hard to sing along.

8/10 damn hard song

I have to admit, I wasn't expecting much of this game when I first saw it. Not even because it looked good or bad, but just because I never bothered to look much into it, despite the fact that it has a big manly lumberjack on its main Steam picture (lumberjacks are awesome!).

In terms of graphics, I'll admit the game doesn't look that amazing, but that's understandable considering this is the studio's first game and the game's price. However, the atmosphere that's presented completely balances this off, by making you forget about the simple and sometimes clunky models with its pure Canadian charm. I'm Canadian, I live in Quebec, I love snow, I love the night, and I can absolutely guarantee that this game feels very authentic. This mood is even backed up by Canadian folk music.

Even the story feels very Canadian, using myths and legends that are very historical, which also includes native folklore. At some points I'd play the game and think to myself this reminds me of that one folk tale I read in high school..."

One of the great little gems to shine out of the cacaphony overload of indie games on Steam. I grew up in minnesota, so when I saw werewolves, and canadian foklore, and RTS AND action...I hit the purchase button faster than a Wendigo sneezes ice. It has a great folky soundtrack, and great hand-drawn visuals, especially the menu and town interfaces.

Being that it is indeed an indie game, the game budgets and amount of people working on this  title would be laughable to a mega-corp like Ubisoft or the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly EA. So there are a few expected rough areas, but they don't detract from the overall game. Mainly, the voice acting was terrible, I felt like random people off the street were pulled in to read children’s books to 1rst graders. If they every make a TOME II, it would be great if they addressed this. Conversely, the sounds while playing the game and the music are very well done. It really sends a shiver up your spine playing this in your room at night, the sounds of the wind rushing through trees, the crack of branches and snarls and howls of the beasts just over the hill expertly done to always create the feeling you will be attacked at any moment.

Mechanically the game works pretty smooth, and is challenging to say the least. It creates tense and relentless action when you hit the go button; it actually is scary in a way. There is a sense of dread and nervousness as you hover your mouse over the ‘begin’ button…setting in motion the nights terrors upon you.  You hope things will work out and you will survive, but it always feels as if the odds are stacked against you. My one complaint is the pacing...the skill tree becoming unlocked only started to open up toward the end, and by the time I could really afford some better weapons, there were only a couple missions left. I wish there was a patch to adjust this a bit. I love a challenge, but I hate seeing cool things that I can't afford and can't have fun using, then it’s over. When it was over though, I can say it was definitely a sense of accomplishment! This makes me want to go back now, play with the harder brother and see if I can get those last few achievements, which are not just filler achievements.

Overall, for a couple bucks, this game is well worth it, is unique, and hope to see their next game...though it looks vastly different in theme. A great 'first' game for this small team in Canada!

Now here's a game that caught me by surprise. Sang Froid: Tales of Werewolves is Montreal-based Artifice Studio's first title, and in spite of some general shabbiness in its presentation, they've done enough things right here that I'll be keeping an eye out for their future releases.

In Sang Froid, you play a pair of Canadian woodsman brothers, defending their sister (as well as the surrounding community) from nightly assaults by supernatural forces both Christian and Pagan in nature. Gameplay takes the form of an innovative and wonderfully executed combination of chop-em-up action, clever tower defense, and Rainbow Six-style tactical planning. Each day presents you with a chunk of storyline, and then lets you spend your limited daylight hours setting up traps on your property or logging at the local lumber yard for extra cash (which is spent on weapons, items, and some of the more dramatic and powerful trap-types). Thanks to your psychic sister, you know ahead of time what kinds of enemies will be attacking, where they'll come from, and what they intend to destroy; setting appropriate traps for each situation is crucial to survival, as you can only be in one place at a time, and your combat prowess is hardly a match for a single werewolf, let alone a pack of several.

When night falls, the assault begins and you get to see if your defenses hold up. Armed with an axe, a rifle, and whatever consumables you've brought with you, you must do everything in your power to wipe out the assaulting units. At its simplest, you can engage opponents in melee, killing off opponents that you either hadn't set traps for or which manage to survive whatever you'd prepared. While the controls are a little wobbly at times, the combat options are innovative, simple, and very intelligent. When you aren't out busting skulls, however, your job will be to run from trap to trap, activating them at the right time to deal the most damage, or letting the enemy catch your scent and then luring them to their fiery/spiky/bouldery doom. Several enemies are very resilient to your weapon attacks, and without intelligent use of traps they can be nearly unbeatable in hand-to-hand combat. You can get around this by wielding blessed or silver weaponry, but you can only carry one axe at a time, and you can't have it both ways.

I haven't had this much fun with a game in a long, long time. All the trap varieties are useful in their own way, adding interesting layers to the strategy. Plotting out the most effective and efficient layout to take out enemies is a bit intimidating at first, but quickly becomes very satisfying; there's nothing quite like knowing you've set up a fool-proof murder gauntlet and then seeing it work like a charm. Running through the woods, sneaking up on your prey as it munches on the bait you've left out; or ziplining over the forest to engage a band of demons at precisely the right moment... Each night's encounter is demanding enough to make you work for it, and all the elements involved in pulling it off are simply fun. Based purely on the gameplay, Sang Froid is an easy title to recommend.

It does have a few weaknesses though. The game suffers beneath an occasionally stuttery framerate, no-budget cutscenes, fairly basic character models, a script that's difficult to take seriously, and a voice acting cast made up of amateurs (several of whom likely have English as a second language). This is more than counterbalanced by a gorgeous musical score, an unorthodox and inventive setting that drowns out the actual writing, and the stellar gameply mentioned above. If it weren't for the fact that nobody seems to know it exists, I'd say Sang Froid has all the makings of a truly great cult classic.

A continuing evolution of the Tower Defense + OTS Combat genre, Sang-Froid strikes an amazing balance between so many different gameplay elements. A dark and well crafted story weaves the campaign together and keeps you engaged from start to finish.

During the day you can examine the types of monsters that will attack during the next night and the routes they'll take. You then use your time units and money to place traps. Leftover time can be used to generate additional funds, which can be spent in the town on weapons, ammo, trinkets, and consumables.

By tying money and time together, Sang-Froid forces you to make tough decisions when planning your day. It's a balance between putting the bare-minimum of traps down so you can afford upgrades without getting yourself killing the process.

Combat at night is fun and tense, with good controls and a variety of monsters that need special tactics to take down. You'll find yourself juggling defending different objectives and, once again, your greatest enemy is time as you fight to clear one attack as quickly as possible so you can make it to the next objective in time.

Over-all a great game on many levels, and a must-buy for anyone that enjoys Tower Defense, werewolves, or strategic OTS combat.

Before I begin, I should note that what I played was a pre-release version of the game. Any bugs have likely been polished off in the final release.

Sang-Froid: Tales of Werewolves is a tower defense/action game with light RPG elements developed by by Artifice Studios, an indie team, with story from Bryan Perro, author of the Amos Daragon series of fantasy novels.

At the beginning of the game, you choose to play one of two brothers: the lumberjack Joseph O'Carrell, or his older brother Jack. Each day, you must set traps in strategic locations to defend your house from werewolves and worse during the night. Joseph does slightly more melee damage than Jack, and is the easy mode" character. Playing as Jack requires you to rely more on your traps.

reviewText: Let me start this review/ reccomendation by saying this: This is the most Canadian game in exsistance. Never has there been a game more Canadian. So disclaimer, if you do not like Canadians ( or thinking, since it is a stratagy game) this is not the game for you. Now that thats done with, lets begin.\nSang Froid: Tales of Werewolves is an action/ stratagy blend set in Canada( go figure) in the late 1850's. It follows Jack and Jos defending their land and their sister from attacks from hell. Night after night new paths open up, and occasionally new buildings to defend, making it harder for you to defend. Sang Froid: Tales of Werewolves is a great reddemer to Werewolves and Canadians alike since the series that shall not be named ( I know its set in Washington State, but everyone is more Canadian than American, and if you cant figure out what it is then heres a hint: Still a better love story than ________.

This game is unique in its capacity for fun. It combines the elements of a classic staategy with that of a third person fighting game and an over the shoulder shooter. The story is brilliant, if not a bit mystical, and while the character design may solicit a few giggles this game is notihing if not challenging and fun. Also, the name is pronounced Sahn Fwa.\n7/10
One of the best Indies 2013

Sang-Froid has an awesome combination of third-person action and a strategic, tower defense-esque concept which is employed at the start of each in-game day and will later help when fighting the wolves themselves. This is a perfect game to buy in the sales as I got for around £5 and it is definitely a good investment of your time and money.
I've never thought that this game will be so good and addicting !

Every effort was made to try and not ruin the plot of the game throughout this review. However, no promises can be made.

***Possible Spoilers follow***

An amazing game for the price.  It is definitely unique, albeit a tad bit easy.  I started the game with Jos, although I really wanted Jack because I was hoping for more gunplay.  Changed to Jack after day 3 because it seemed a bit too easy to NOT play on the mode I had originally wanted.

Although I found the gunplay severely lacking, I still enjoyed the game.  Honestly, aside from shooting Net traps or occasionally shooting enemies as they ran up, I rarely used my gun at all.  Even sitting on bonfires, I found it more advantageous to run out, do a full combo once or twice, and then run back into the saftey zone of the warming flames.

However, when you think about it, that merges great with the historical and realistic (for a game about demons and werewolves) feel that the developers were trying to create. It wouldn't make much sense for you to be running around with a musket firing off round after round during the time period the game takes place in.

I wasn't entirely thrilled by everything in the game though.  I spent a lot of the nights just sitting around waiting on my traps to go off and still using a good chunk of my AP on cutting lumber for money.  I actually found myself purposefully letting enemies get to my buildings each wave so I would have something to do.  If you understand how the traps work, you could literally clear almost every wave with traps alone.

Overall the combat system itself was poorly made.  You get your autoattack" consisting of left clicking up to 3 times for a combo (and with your stamina thats about 6-8 clicks until you fatigue) or rightclicking to spend your "rage" points. Once you learn the system its pretty childish.  Left click combo (3 clicks) to knock an enemy down
date: run / sprint in circles (run around and only sprint when they get close to avoid attack)
recommended: and then combo again and repeat. Throw in an occasional Right-Click for a stamina-free attack/knockdown here and there. Doing this you could take on Wendigos and The Invisible Beast no problem. After around days 3-5 I never found myself using the roll (spacebar) except during fights with the "Fireflies". There was just no point in wasting all that stamina when a quick sprint away would dodge most if not all attacks and leave you with a lot more stamina.\n\nThe "Fireflies" were probably the most annoying thing in the game.  Before you get the hang of fighting them

An interesting combination of 3rd person shooter, strategy/tower defense and rpg elements.

The mechanics are simple; place traps to help you kill enemies, to get more money to buy more traps and gear to help you kill more enemies. Lather, rinse, repeat.

The voice acting is... well, not great, but not the worst I've come across. The story, however, is kind of interesting which warrents the price.

The stratgy elements her isn't done in real-time, so once you place your traps and start the night, you're on your own. And traps are one-time-use, and once their gone, even if you have a massive wave of enemies still to come, you're left with just yourself to fend off the hordes... but that's not a bad thing. Not letting you place traps whenever forces you to plan ahead, and not just be reactive. And with traps being limited, you have to be even more careful and make each trap count.

Part-strategy, part-action, with a good skill selection tree, two difficulty setting using the two main characters and Canadian lore (we have lore?). Add to that an appealing art style, A+ music appropriate to the setting (also best loading music ever) decent voice acting and a intriguing story, this may be the best lumberjacks vs werewolves game I've ever played...well, ok, it's the only one but that doesn't lessen my enthusiasm.  4/5 A little bit of frame rate issues during some battles is the only detrimental mark against it.

Canadian Gothic Horror Tower Defense!\nYes, it is as awesome as it sounds. The Devil himself has corrupted a nearby village and seeks a girl currently recovering in your cabin. Together with the few remaining townspeople, you have to defeat the armies of Wolf Packs, Werewolves and Dark Spirits that assault you during the night. Use the daylight wisely to plan your strategy and stock up on supplies, and slay the armies of Satan after nightfall.\nThe game combines the round-based tower defense design with a very unique combat system. Use Shouts, Baits and Campfires to turn your foe's natural instincts against them! And to top it all off, it has a true Canadian angle to it. Very cool game!

I was once lost, a shell of a man wandering this modern world. I kept asking myself, Was I born too late? Did I miss my true era?" When a man yerns for the rustic outdoors...when he wishes he could carve himself a corn-cobbed pipe
date: drink a pint of whiskey and go chop down white pine trees in the wintery north wearing nothing but a flanel shirt and wool pants...he should think of Sang-Froid. Every level I played of this game made me want to drink like a lumberjack till I couldn't feel feelings then wrestle a bear with my shirt off. And every morning I'm forced to shave off the magnificent beard that grew thanks to this game's ungodly manliness it bestowed upon me. If you too wish to be a woodland-god of testosterone whose mere glance causes wolverines to wet themselves in fear then by god you have to buy Sang-Froid now. It will change your life."

I'm not usually a fan of tower defense style games, but I actually enjoyed this game quite a bit. You fight off waves of enemies, but using traps and your own musket. There is an interesting fear mechanic, and levels are challenging while giving you an ammount of freedom in how to approach them. There are RPG elements that gave enough choices to make me feel like I was powerful while at the same time always leaving me wishing for the next level or making hard choices. Finally, with the time period, plot, and music, I enjoyed the games style. It isn't the longest or best game you will play, but I think it was well worth the $15.

I like Sang-Froid - Tales of Werewolves for 3 reasons:

1) The game play - It has a great mix between 3rd person action (smashing wolfs with axes, guns and what not); stragety in terms of placement of fire, traps and where you put your charcter & upgrading of your weapons and traps between the action.

2) I love the setting - and the idea of a remote french canadian forrest town harrased by warewolves.

3) Different monsters require different tactics making you try different ways to bring them down



What i didnt like about it:


a) I found the story is a bit weak and i ended up skipping the cutsceans towards the end - i just didnt buy into the emotion behind saving your sick sister - the voice acting was fine, but it could perhaps have better script writing.

b) Ended too quickly - just when i was getting into the gameplay it was all over.

c) Little replayability - some variety is very much needed to make me want to play it again, such as a much harder difficulty level so i can test my skills - also some randomisation in where the monsters spawn as once you have fuigured out the tactic to a map - there is little incentivve to try another tactic.

Would i recomend it? YES! and i very much hope the developers will relsease an expansion / DLC with more maps, more characters, more weapons as the gameplay is very fun and is the true highlight og the game.

Interesting game, it takes mutliple elements and fuses them. Theres fps, tower defence, rpg, and a story. So when I go to the Indian village they are saying I travel from Canada and cross the ocean and find a village in India.  Indians are in India which is in Asia. Stop calling natives Indians.

Great concept and well put together. Can be played using a variety of different strategies, character level ups can give game a very different feel for different play throughs.  Looking forward to the next chapter.

Note that this review is based on just a few hours of play; I haven't completed the game yet.

Let me get this out of the way first: The cutscenes, both cinematic and in-engine, are pretty terrible and the story isn't anything to write home about.  The animation doesn't look especially good, the voice acting is sometimes questionable (on top of that, they don't pronounce things right for French Canadians which hurts my suspension of disbelief), and the writing occasionally veers into downright cringe-worthy.  I still appreciate that the cutscenes are there, since they do at least tie the missions/nights together, but I don't really enjoy them, per se.

Sang-Froid is sort of a combination 3rd-person action game and tower defense strategy, and fortunately, it pulls the gameplay off reasonably well.  The strategic and tactical elements of planning out your traps and then trying to execute your plan is quite satisfying.  The game has a surprising amount of little intricate details, like how your enemies can track you via sound and scent, and how you can use an intimidation system to buy yourself some breathing room, which come together with a variety of traps, many of which require some manual management on your part, to make a game that you can actually sometimes feel cunning during.  In a testament to the developers' enemy design, the monsters actually feel fairly varied, even though their variety is in reality little more than rock-paper-scissors, and they kind of fall to the same axework.

The game is at its strongest when you're planning your traps out, or rushing across the map to trip a net full of rocks just in the nick onf time.  You really get caught up in the moment, watching your plans come to fruition, or hearing the distant sound of a spike trap impaling a bunch of wolves while you're in the middle of a fight.

Unfortunately, the combat system doesn't measure up to the traps.  The ranged combat system has a far too aggressive auto-aim.  It's useful when you're trying to line up shots on circling wolves, as the rifle is meant to fire too slowly to make manual aiming feel rewarding.  But when you're trying to trigger one out of several clustered traps of nets filled with rocks, the game's inability to know which one you actually wanted to shoot as their autoaim fights each other can completely ruin a trap.  Not being able to move while reloading is frustraing, but I understand and accept the developer's decision in that regard, as it does make shooting the rifle mean" more -- it makes using the weapon a resource beyond just the ammunition it takes
date: as the reload time can be a serious liability in the middle of a wave of enemies.\n\nThe melee combat system feels clunky and vague.  It's more like Don't Starve than Arkham Asylum or Assassin's Creed.  While hitting enemies with your axe is rewarding
recommended: the enemy "tells" for attacks are generally not obvious enough to make the dodge system really pay off.  You'll hit a werewolf twice
hoursPlayed: then suddenly get knocked over when they attack back
voteText: seemingly without warning.  You also have little control over what you're doing beyond "swing axe
helpfulPercent:
so sometimes you'll knock enemies away when you'd rather be pressing the attack.  I find myself perpetually short of stamina, which probably means I'm fighting wrong, but it still is frustrating.   The real problem though is that while the enemies behave differently in terms of traps, in combat, they all seem to fight pretty much the same; or at least your tactics for fighting are pretty much the same.  All that changes is which weapon the enemy is particularly vulnerable to, which doesn't make for especially satisfying combat.  (Then again, I get the feeling that melee combat is *supposed* to be somewhat discouraged in the game, and almost making it dull does sort of discourage it.)

Each night is pretty short, but can be reasonably intense as the timing of some of your traps can be quite tight.  This gives each mission an almost bite-sized quality, so it's easy to play a couple nights in spite of a busy schedule.  It also lends itself to the just one more" phenomenon in a way that longer missions would not.

Sang-Froid has its rough spots
votesHelpful: but I feel that the game realizes the goals it set out to achieve
votesTotal: and by keeping itself short and sweet it manages to emphasize its fun parts and keeps the less fun parts from becoming tedious."

This is a pretty fun game!  The theming is very well done, I like the vast majority of the artwork a whole lot, the music is awesome, and the gameplay is really enjoyable!  I would compare this game to something like Orcs Must Die!, but with slightly more emphasis on planning and strategy, and with a tiny bit of resource management (time units & money) to spice things up a little.\n\nI do acknowledge that this is an indie game, and I don't want to seem like I'm judging it unfairly, but my only real criticism of Sang-Froid is that I don't much care for the character model close-ups during the cutscenes (they are perfectly adequate for normal gameplay, however), and that I think better voice acting, perhaps with some/more exaggerated French-Canadian accents, would have gone a long way toward keeping with the terrific atmosphere the rest of the game is brimming with, and also toward justifying the $14.99 price tag.  Personally, I feel like that's ever-so-slightly high -- I would've purchased this game at some point before it went on sale, if the full price was closer to $9.99.  That said, this game is an absolute STEAL at the current sale price of $3.74!

Sweet merciful heavens is this game weird.  And I love it.  Sang Froid is a strange beast.  I know it won't be for everyone, but for me, it was pure bliss.  The story is actually fairly unique, taking a different spin on the werewolf lore than the usual and throwing in some native american lore for good measure.  While it is a bit campy, it's fun and one of the most Canadian games in existence.  It has great flavor and atmosphere.

But how is the combat?  In a word, clunky.  The game mixes setting traps, some automatic and some you have to trigger, alongside fighting in third person.  The traps are very cool, but the fighting itself is a bit awkward to get around, whether it's swinging your axe or aiming your gun.  However, if you can get past that, it is a ton of fun.  There are some ingenious mechanics, such as having to take into account how your scent is carried on the wind, the long load times of a musket rifle, and how afraid your enemies are of you.  This, combined with setting traps and planning your battles in the day, and actually fighting at night, makes for an addictive experience.

Comes highly recommended.  I played through both campaigns and loved each of them.

This game is very well-designed and really original! The visuals and voice acting may be a bit terrible but the gameplay is rock-solid and matches the theme perfectly. A real gem that I highly recommend!

Written by Canadian author Bryan Perro and produced by Artifice Studio, Sang-Froid: Tales of Werewolves is best described as a strategy game with action elements.  You begin the game as one of two feuding brothers.  One remains in the cabin with your sick sister, while the brother you select to play, is responsible for protecting the homestead from the increasing waves and ferocity of wolves, supernatural and mythical beasties, which appear when night arrives.  Your aim is simple – survive the night.

To achieve this, you set traps, fire your musket and swing your trusty axe.  As the game progresses, you learn new traps and are able to upgrade your equipment by visiting the nearby town or Indian reservation.   This includes blessing your axe and bullets in order that they may be more effective against certain beasts.

The story of this game unfolds during each day that takes place after you’ve survived a night.  It’s a simple, but effective tale of omens, superstition, possession, greed and lust.  It explores a conflict between good and evil that overtakes a small Canadian town and nearby forest.  The voice acting is solid - I loved the Mayor’s confession – plus, I found the tale to be well scripted.  I also loved how the story was presented.  It’s a 2D affair using striking cartoon characters, beautifully rendered with strong colours and decisive design.

I found the gameplay straightforward.  You begin with a map of the area that will be affected during the night by the next attack of supernatural forces.  These are shown in waves.  You are able to see the starting point of each group of wolves, werewolves etc., and can access details of the route to the building they will attack.  This information allows you to plan your defence and place traps in the places where they will be most effective.  You also plan how to use bait and scent to lure the beasts, plus traps can be combined to devastating effect.   However, some beasts will escape, evade or be only partially damaged by your traps, which is where sharpshooting and your axe come into play.  Once a night is set in motion, the game is in third person 3D.

Character development uses an RPG style skill tree.  Here you improve your characters performance, the strength of your traps, the ferocity of your axe and length of your bonfires.  You can also increase your intimidation, or fear, factor which is surprisingly useful.  As stamina plays a major role in how much you can do, being able to intimidate means you gain recovery time.  Yes, you can role and manoeuvre away from a beast, but this does deplete your stamina.  In addition, if surrounded by a pack of wolves there is only so much manoeuvring you can do.   Naturally stamina is an aspect of your character’s performance you can improve, but hard choices have to be made.

Sang-Froid: Tales of Werewolves drew me in, engaged me, delighted me and was an incredibly satisfying experience.  The first three nights are instructional; the ones which follow gradually step the game up a gear, until what appeared to be a straightforward scenario becomes pretty darn complex.  You don’t know if your strategy will succeed until you survive the night but, when your chosen brother steps out into the pool of light surrounding the homestead and you find yourself poised, ready to go, with your traps set and your plan for the first wave firmly implanted in your mind, you’ll know the game has entrapped you.

This is one of the coolest single player games I've ever played.

It takes place in lower Canada during the winter of 1858, where you get to play as one of these two bad ♥♥♥ Canadian lumberjacks (lol), and fight the devil and his minions as they make nightly advances on your lil sister.

The story is great; the dialog doesn't seem to hold back, and best of all, it isn't riddled with your standard - yet unrealistic - politically correct undertones. This really adds to the immersion in my opinion, considering the time period. It's also co-written with best selling author Bryan Perro!

Lastly, the game play has been very fun; typically I've found tower defense games don't offer a consistent challenge; and can be very boring for the majority of the content. This one however has a cool mechanic wherein you may forgo some of your allotted towers" for bonus $ or score
date: allowing the player to dynamically increase the difficulty of both the strategic stage AND the action-oriented stage of any level."

Well, I'm not that far but I'm already hooked. Something a lot of recent games do not accomplish. This game is one hell of a genre mix (imagine a RPG-Hack&Slay-Tower-Defense-Game). I recommend this game to:

- anyone liking strategy games
- anyone aren't annoyed by tower defense games (it has a little bit of those since you must defend certain objectives like your house or a mill etc.)
- people who like to get more involved in-character" (unlike most RTS like Starcraft etc.) and are not averse of a little bit hack & slay.

This game is NOT for people seeking a true challenge/want to play online or expect a serious horror adventure with an intensive story or just can't stand any werewolf kind of scenarios.

Every effort was made to try and not ruin the plot of the game throughout this review. However, no promises can be made.

***Possible Spoilers follow***

An amazing game for the price.  It is definitely unique, albeit a tad bit easy.  I started the game with Jos, although I really wanted Jack because I was hoping for more gunplay.  Changed to Jack after day 3 because it seemed a bit too easy to NOT play on the mode I had originally wanted.

Although I found the gunplay severely lacking, I still enjoyed the game.  Honestly, aside from shooting Net traps or occasionally shooting enemies as they ran up, I rarely used my gun at all.  Even sitting on bonfires, I found it more advantageous to run out, do a full combo once or twice, and then run back into the saftey zone of the warming flames.

However, when you think about it, that merges great with the historical and realistic (for a game about demons and werewolves) feel that the developers were trying to create. It wouldn't make much sense for you to be running around with a musket firing off round after round during the time period the game takes place in.

I wasn't entirely thrilled by everything in the game though.  I spent a lot of the nights just sitting around waiting on my traps to go off and still using a good chunk of my AP on cutting lumber for money.  I actually found myself purposefully letting enemies get to my buildings each wave so I would have something to do.  If you understand how the traps work, you could literally clear almost every wave with traps alone.

Overall the combat system itself was poorly made.  You get your autoattack" consisting of left clicking up to 3 times for a combo (and with your stamina thats about 6-8 clicks until you fatigue) or rightclicking to spend your "rage" points. Once you learn the system its pretty childish.  Left click combo (3 clicks) to knock an enemy down
date: run / sprint in circles (run around and only sprint when they get close to avoid attack)
recommended: and then combo again and repeat. Throw in an occasional Right-Click for a stamina-free attack/knockdown here and there. Doing this you could take on Wendigos and The Invisible Beast no problem. After around days 3-5 I never found myself using the roll (spacebar) except during fights with the "Fireflies". There was just no point in wasting all that stamina when a quick sprint away would dodge most if not all attacks and leave you with a lot more stamina.\n\nThe "Fireflies" were probably the most annoying thing in the game.  Before you get the hang of fighting them
hoursPlayed: you will find youself constanly trying to take one down
voteText: only to find yourself slammed in the back by a fireball from another one and knocked down while the one you were fighting disappears underground to heal himself back up to full.  And thanks to the aforementioned combat system

you will still find yourself catching the occasional fireball and cursing at them.

No problem (although a ballista will take it out in 1 shot with the skill point). I wouldn't recommend fighting a Wendigo hand-to-hand (because they cannot be knocked down
column18: only backwards)

but it is still pretty easy. And the Fireflies become cake. 15 Health? Kinda annoying to fight when they're resistant and can heal.  After the axe they go down in about 4 or 5 swings.

Later on when the wolves come in packs of 3 there is little point to it. I put 1 point in trapping just so it would hold things (mainly Maikkans) for 10 seconds so I could set a spike trap and wait for more enemies to run up on the one stuck in place. Spike traps were better for the wolves because at 55 AP they save you AP and you can set them on the spawn point to drop the packs as soon as they zone in. I liked a lot of things about this game. It has an excellent soundtrack, an aesthetic style that's likely to keep its graphics from feeling dated as quickly as a triple A title, gameplay that's easy to get a handle on but tough to master, and a suitable difficulty that never feels cheap or contrived despite being a fairly challenging game. It isn't perfect, but it has excellent flavor, enjoyable gameplay, a surprisingly well written story despite its sometimes campy delivery, and is overall fun and worth the price of admission.

Score : 8/10

A beautiful meld of 3rd Person Action and strategy set in early 1800s Canadian woods, swinging heavily towards strategy part. Main goal of the game is to defend various buildings of importance from the attacks of wolves and werewolves during the night by setting up traps during the day. Selection and placement of traps is incredibly important, it's almost like a puzzle game. Game doesn't force you solve every puzzle perfectly though. When things don't go the way you hoped you can always let your axe do some of the work. You can also customize your character with unlockable skills and items which opens up different solutions.

Story is rather interesting, presented almost as a graphic novel. Really nice soundtrack and probably the best musket action I've seen in a game. What's also worth noting is how well the enemies and combat are balanced. You won't be facing generic tower defense creeps which die by the dozens when you sneeze at them. Game really makes you respect the enemies here as even a single werewolf can make you sweat if you mess up your traps.

Overall, anyone who's into one of either strategy, tower defense, puzzle or resource management will really enjoy this game.
Doesn't get much more French Canadian than this!

Although i would have loved this as a co-op game where one is the melee lumberjack and the other was the quiet sniper in the towers, this is one of the best games i have played in a long time and i would highly recommend it for anyone who loves strategy and high paced action all in one. :)

I didn't like the animations or voice acting. I want to see a sandbox option, where I can set up the map and then play. That was missing. The game play was lacking and the charecters had little depth. The only thing that set the mood was the beginning intro movie/art. After that.... the graphics failed the game and didnt follow the artistic intro.

Misleading is the best summary I can give. From the trailer, it looked like a great hack and slash with tactical planning, but ended up having Rainbow Six bloopers where if you don't do everything perfectly, you are screwed.

The graphics are pretty good. They remind me of a  launch title for the PS2. I don't like how little I can adjust the graphics and because of the lowest settings available, it isn't fluid for frame rates (I hover around 40 instead of the preferred 60). I can't even adjust the resolution outside of my monitor (16:10), so I'm forced to 1244x800 instead of picking something lower when there are options to select lower.

The reaction times for attack animations are a bit off. The stamina bar affects attack speed, but creatures like the werewolf tended to almost blink towards me like a flash step and I couldn't swing to counter attack in time. Things like that prevent  a lot tactical fighting, especially when certain creatures like the Were-wolf are too fast to run away from and you'll pretty much die if you don't strike first with a trap.

Sound effects are passable. I wanted to listen to my own music fairly quickly, but the intro song alone was pretty good while it took two full minutes to load on a fairly modern machine. (made in 2011 with the latest parts at the time).

All together it is frustrating to the point I don't want to spend too much time replaying levels because of the inability for the characters to be useful. It is Rainbow Six all over again and the old Rainbox Six games were cool atmosphere but quit-inducing rage sessions due to bad AI and weird decisions from the Devs for gameplay, just like this game.

As this is on sale now I though I might give a short recommendation. This game is possibly the most unique strategy game I've seen. It offers a wide variety of innovative and unique gameplay mechanics. The levels play as both a tower defense puzzle where you place elaborate traps around the map in order to take enemies out passively, and as an RPG with strategy components where you engage the enemies actively with rifle and axe. The fear meter is a very interesting mechanic where the actions of the enemy depend on the amount of fear both you and your enemies have. For the discounted price (€2,- here) this game is absolutely worth it. It is also the most Canadian game ever.

reviewText: Tower defense meets survivalist.  A very nice change from the standard 3rd person defense game.

Most PC gamers are no strangers to strategy games. As much as I love a good strategy title, sometimes I want to get right into the action. In this, Sang-Froid: Tales of Werewolves delivers, offering the best blend of action and strategy I've played since Brütal Legend. During the day, players prepare for the night's onslaught by purchasing items, setting traps, and preparing a plan of action. Oh, and I don't use the word onslaught" lightly. The wolves will attack you relentlessly
date: and if you lose a single building
recommended: it's game over. You'll need to carefully plan ahead and act fast to survive and scrape together a living in this game. It takes the critical thinking of a strategy game and combines it with the frantic action of a brawler. Combine this with the clever "fear" mechanic-wherein you can keep attacks at bay for a short time-and you've got an intense nail-biter of a game.\n\nThe game's pretty rough around the edges. It's certainly not the best looking game
hoursPlayed: with a somewhat barren and uninteresting landscape. It manages to get away with it for the most part by incorporating a pleasing aesthetic
voteText: but it only goes so far. In addition
helpfulPercent: it's combat is fairly rudimentary

votesTotal: the action side of things isn't quite as polished.\n\nSang-Froid: Tales of Werewolves combines two genres well enough that I can overlook some of its rougher edges
votesFunny: and enjoy one hell of an intense action strategy experience."

reviewText: You are Canada Guy. Your sister is hunted by furries. Are you a bad enough dude to burn them in the Emperor's name?\n\nOf course you are. You are Canada Guy.

Sweet merciful heavens is this game weird.  And I love it.  Sang Froid is a strange beast.  I know it won't be for everyone, but for me, it was pure bliss.  The story is actually fairly unique, taking a different spin on the werewolf lore than the usual and throwing in some native american lore for good measure.  While it is a bit campy, it's fun and one of the most Canadian games in existence.  It has great flavor and atmosphere.

But how is the combat?  In a word, clunky.  The game mixes setting traps, some automatic and some you have to trigger, alongside fighting in third person.  The traps are very cool, but the fighting itself is a bit awkward to get around, whether it's swinging your axe or aiming your gun.  However, if you can get past that, it is a ton of fun.  There are some ingenious mechanics, such as having to take into account how your scent is carried on the wind, the long load times of a musket rifle, and how afraid your enemies are of you.  This, combined with setting traps and planning your battles in the day, and actually fighting at night, makes for an addictive experience.

Comes highly recommended.  I played through both campaigns and loved each of them.

This game is very well-designed and really original! The visuals and voice acting may be a bit terrible but the gameplay is rock-solid and matches the theme perfectly. A real gem that I highly recommend!

Written by Canadian author Bryan Perro and produced by Artifice Studio, Sang-Froid: Tales of Werewolves is best described as a strategy game with action elements.  You begin the game as one of two feuding brothers.  One remains in the cabin with your sick sister, while the brother you select to play, is responsible for protecting the homestead from the increasing waves and ferocity of wolves, supernatural and mythical beasties, which appear when night arrives.  Your aim is simple – survive the night.

To achieve this, you set traps, fire your musket and swing your trusty axe.  As the game progresses, you learn new traps and are able to upgrade your equipment by visiting the nearby town or Indian reservation.   This includes blessing your axe and bullets in order that they may be more effective against certain beasts.

The story of this game unfolds during each day that takes place after you’ve survived a night.  It’s a simple, but effective tale of omens, superstition, possession, greed and lust.  It explores a conflict between good and evil that overtakes a small Canadian town and nearby forest.  The voice acting is solid - I loved the Mayor’s confession – plus, I found the tale to be well scripted.  I also loved how the story was presented.  It’s a 2D affair using striking cartoon characters, beautifully rendered with strong colours and decisive design.

I found the gameplay straightforward.  You begin with a map of the area that will be affected during the night by the next attack of supernatural forces.  These are shown in waves.  You are able to see the starting point of each group of wolves, werewolves etc., and can access details of the route to the building they will attack.  This information allows you to plan your defence and place traps in the places where they will be most effective.  You also plan how to use bait and scent to lure the beasts, plus traps can be combined to devastating effect.   However, some beasts will escape, evade or be only partially damaged by your traps, which is where sharpshooting and your axe come into play.  Once a night is set in motion, the game is in third person 3D.

Character development uses an RPG style skill tree.  Here you improve your characters performance, the strength of your traps, the ferocity of your axe and length of your bonfires.  You can also increase your intimidation, or fear, factor which is surprisingly useful.  As stamina plays a major role in how much you can do, being able to intimidate means you gain recovery time.  Yes, you can role and manoeuvre away from a beast, but this does deplete your stamina.  In addition, if surrounded by a pack of wolves there is only so much manoeuvring you can do.   Naturally stamina is an aspect of your character’s performance you can improve, but hard choices have to be made.

Sang-Froid: Tales of Werewolves drew me in, engaged me, delighted me and was an incredibly satisfying experience.  The first three nights are instructional; the ones which follow gradually step the game up a gear, until what appeared to be a straightforward scenario becomes pretty darn complex.  You don’t know if your strategy will succeed until you survive the night but, when your chosen brother steps out into the pool of light surrounding the homestead and you find yourself poised, ready to go, with your traps set and your plan for the first wave firmly implanted in your mind, you’ll know the game has entrapped you.

SNAPSHOT
An action-RPG / tower defense game that looks like it was made by third graders. Thankfully, it plays like an 8th grade level.

OVERALL - 3.5 / 10

PROS
+ combat feels responsive
+ music is good
+ planning each level is interesting
+ relatively bug free (unless you're trying to get achievements, in which case the opposite of that)

CONS
- awful models (texturing is ok at best)
- awful voice acting
- awful writing
- way too many game mechanics overly complicates almost every portion of the game
- replaying levels *intentionally* disincentivized
- every level uses the same map for the entire game

DETAILS
Where to even begin with this one. I really wanted to like Sang-Froid, I really did. Overall I like the concept of an action-RPG + tower defense game (Orcs Must Die! does it fairly well), and the movement in the game doesn't play all that poorly, but overall it is extremely poorly executed.

Probably my biggest gripe is that combat-related gameplay itself is just a pile-on of systems that's only purposes seem to be to limit what the player can do. First there is stamina, which is a combined limit of being able to run as well as your ability to use melee combat. Melee is frustratingly bad, especially the targeting. Often times you'll be attacking an enemy that's about to die and then suddenly the game will switch targets on you and you'll be swinging at something else on the other side of the screen, leaving that low health enemy free to do whatever it wants (which 90% of the time means regen to full or cast a meteor swarm down on your face). It becomes even MORE frustrating when enemies start becoming ~90% resistant to normal damage, so unless you have a weapon the enemy is weak to you won't be doing full damage. Ranged combat requires you to reload after every single shot you take, which takes an inordinate amount of time (there's an *achievement* for reloading in under 3 seconds). You can speed up reloading slightly by mashing a button, which seems to only distract the player from how long it actually takes. Also of note for ranged combat is that it has headshot and non-headshot hitboxes that lock on" (poorly) that are infuriating more often than not. Next
date: there's a "fear" system that was supposed to help players not fight enemies all the time
recommended: but in practice way too complicated and cumbersome. On top of all of this there are still traps for players to place
hoursPlayed: each of which only has *one* use per level (seriously?) per trap placed.\n\nPaired with this combat system is ~ 3 different enemies (there's one ranged enemy in the game
voteText: and then a few minor variations of a melee enemy) and *one* map that goes through extremely minor changes and expands slightly between levels. Also of note are the "two" characters to choose from
helpfulPercent: which in reality only vary in starting stats so I'm still not sure why the choice even exists. If there had been half as much time / effort put in to adding all the limiting factors in combat and 4x as much time put into adding real variations in content
votesHelpful: it would have potentially been a much more engaging game. Unfortunately
votesTotal: while it seems all of the development efforts were spent in adding combat systems
votesFunny: combat gets old very quickly without a change in enemies to face. The different starting points and number of enemies each wave helps masks this problem slightly
commentsCount: but that wears thin pretty quickly.\n\nOn top of all of this
column16: replaying levels is almost completely out of the question. You CAN go back to a level you've already completed
column17: however it erases ALL progress past that point. There is one achievement for completing the game for each character
column18: but why anyone would do that is beyond me. The game doesn't play differently for either character
column19: save for the fact that one of them has less health AND stamina than the other. Skill points that are awarded each time a player levels up only seem to annoy a player more than help them
column20: most of which only add minor amounts of damage. The skill points spent almost never make a difference in whether or not an enemy dies; either the damage added is already overkill
column21: or it adds such a minimal amount that you're better off walking up and meleeing them instead.\n\nEasily the worst parts of the game are the "animated cutscenes" between levels. I could forgive the awful models if there were a lot of them (or if this game was made in 2006)
column22: but there are comically few to be seen and it was released in 2013. It is very apparent that the entirety of the modeling / animation efforts in the game were spent on the cutscenes
column23: which there are unfortunately ~1-3 of every single level. The voice acting is as cringe-worthy as the models
column24: and the writing is almost as bad. Given that the story is based on French Canadian folklore
column26: that means 90% of the work was already done story-wise
column27: so how that was screwed up so poorly I'll never know.\n\nOverall
column28: this game has a lot of things in place to distract players from the fact that just about every system was poorly planned and designed
column29: so if you're really into shiny things feel free to pick it up. If you're not easily fooled

reviewText: Buy this fantastic indie game based on Québécois folklore! Challenging but not in a frustrating way, I guarantee you'll get your money's worth.\n\nSoutenez la créativité québécoise. ;)

+ There's definitely something special about Sang-Froid: Tales of Werewolves's combination of action and strategy. Even if sometimes you'll disagree with some of the design decisions, it's unique setting and compelling gameplay will make every victory satisfying.
- Performance is bad. It never became terrible or unplayable, but the almost one minute loading screen and the overall low framerate is as much a mistery for high end PC owners as it is a hindrance to the gameplay.

I have to admit, I wasn't expecting much of this game when I first saw it. Not even because it looked good or bad, but just because I never bothered to look much into it, despite the fact that it has a big manly lumberjack on its main Steam picture (lumberjacks are awesome!).

In terms of graphics, I'll admit the game doesn't look that amazing, but that's understandable considering this is the studio's first game and the game's price. However, the atmosphere that's presented completely balances this off, by making you forget about the simple and sometimes clunky models with its pure Canadian charm. I'm Canadian, I live in Quebec, I love snow, I love the night, and I can absolutely guarantee that this game feels very authentic. This mood is even backed up by Canadian folk music.

Even the story feels very Canadian, using myths and legends that are very historical, which also includes native folklore. At some points I'd play the game and think to myself this reminds me of that one folk tale I read in high school..."

Sang-Froid is a really interesting and innovative hybrid action-strategy game. Each level consists of a planning/strategy phase where you spend time & money to set up traps followed by an action phase where you attempt to defeat the wolves & other enemies with your traps, axe, and musket, earning money for each kill. The voice acting is uneven but none of it's nails-on-chalkboard, the difficulty curve is very smooth, and the in-game tutorials are quite adequate. Also, fun.

I got this for $7.49 during a sale. Warning: This is a indie title. If you can't stand games that are not perfect, turn around now.

Gameplay: You play as one of any two brothers that each night fight to defend their cabin as well as other buildings as you progress. Each night you prepare your map from a top down perspective by putting down traps and obstacles to slow down, damage, and/or kill waves of   werewolves and other creatures. During this time you can also travel to the nerby village to buy supplies(a hub of storefronts). Here buy drinks that heal or give you bonus, supplies, and upgrades your weapons(axe and rifle). When you are ready the night begins and you are put into third person to fight each wave.

The story/animation/voice acting is what you would expect of a indie game. Not terrible, but not that amazing.

If this is for around $5 and don't mind something differen't, give this game a shot. It is one of those gems you never hear about.

A beautiful meld of 3rd Person Action and strategy set in early 1800s Canadian woods, swinging heavily towards strategy part. Main goal of the game is to defend various buildings of importance from the attacks of wolves and werewolves during the night by setting up traps during the day. Selection and placement of traps is incredibly important, it's almost like a puzzle game. Game doesn't force you solve every puzzle perfectly though. When things don't go the way you hoped you can always let your axe do some of the work. You can also customize your character with unlockable skills and items which opens up different solutions.

Story is rather interesting, presented almost as a graphic novel. Really nice soundtrack and probably the best musket action I've seen in a game. What's also worth noting is how well the enemies and combat are balanced. You won't be facing generic tower defense creeps which die by the dozens when you sneeze at them. Game really makes you respect the enemies here as even a single werewolf can make you sweat if you mess up your traps.

Overall, anyone who's into one of either strategy, tower defense, puzzle or resource management will really enjoy this game.
Follows the exact same formula as the horde" made about 15 years ago and staring kirk cameron
date: this is a very nice change of pace.  Fun and smart strategy that isn't hard to learn with many different approaches to dispatching your enemies.  I generally do not like strategy games but this throws in enough 3rd person hack and slash and fps sniping to make it worth 15$ easy.  Not a bread and butter game but enough hours here for 2 thumbs up."

Very Nice game. The strategic and action combines perferctly. The more strategic in the traps you are, the less effort need to be done in combat, but traps cost money and time to build, what really makes you need to be strategic decisions about what traps you will put to balance with the difficulty of the combat, so you can save money for new weapons and accesories.

It also have an leveling system to help you, but that was a little weak, you only gain a skill point when evolve, nothing more, so you don't get stronger for later in the game, also there is no way to get more exp then beating the stages, so basicaly after each stage you gain a skill point to spend in the skill tree.

Even if this is a lower point, it doesn't mess the fun in the game at all. The game is at the right size, 20 stages, and have two difficulties (which is the brother you choose to play), so when you beat the game in normal dificulty, you will end up going for the hard to get all the achivements. Achivements are not impossible to get, as so many games are, what makes it fun to get the 100%. Anyway, the game is great, I recommend. Hope there be a sequel.

Really enjoyed the mix of set-up strategy and in action tactical aspects to this game.  Just ensure that your pc/laptop can fully support it.  Otherwise it doesn't scale down well and the low frame rates make it almost impossible to play.  I say almost as you'll know that you nearly beat that wave/level the last time even with the frame rate issue.  So a minor adjustment to your traps, load out or last level up skill selection would...  It extends the game a lot.

I admit, the game looks a little rough around the edges, but it's a phenomenal take on tower defense games .The cutscenes are a little cheesy, the graphics aren't all that great, but the gameplay is unparalleled. Each 'mission' you have a set amount of money to spend on traps... the more efficient you are at not wasting money, the more money you can spend on better gear/upgrades/etc. This creates a sort of minimalist approach.. you're constantly trying to place as little traps as possible, and setting up a perfect wave by wave traps and backup plans that you can fall back on if something doesn't hit. The feeling of satisfaction you get when you pull of a perfectly planned 5+ wave defense is like nothing I've felt before in a game. Even when something goes amiss and you manage to pull through by the skin of your teeth.. it's great. There's enough RPG skill tree mechanics and 3rd person fighting skill to make it a lot more 'alive' then your normal TD game, too. Buy it! You won't regret it.

Unique and interesting combination of action and a limited amount of strategy with a backdrop of a story (adventure?). I've not come across any bugs, and I've enjoyed it so far, and fully expect to enjoy it some more.

Graphics are of a cartoonish quality - high quality, well drawn, atmospheric - but if you're looking for photorealism, go elsewhere.

No criticisms thus far.  Well worth the small price of admission.

Tower-defense/action hybrids have appeared to become a genre on their own.  Games like Orcs Must Die and Sanctum seem to lead the pack in this realm but Sang-Froid has emerged to be my favorite of this style of game.  First off, I love the aesthetic of the game.  The frozen Canadian frontier in December during the 1800s really appealed to me.  Couple this with the werewolf and Native American lore and I was hooked.  There is story here.  The voice acting and animation definitely show it's indie roots (meaning not that great) but unlike other games of this ilk, I actually paid attention to the narrative.\n\nGameplay wise, strategy is key.  Know where to place your traps and what kind of traps to use is crucial.  The planning phase of this game ended up being more instrumental to me than any other tower defense game.  It was extremely satisfying during missions to here a trap go off somewhere in the distance and know I had a kill.  The combat might be the weakest part of this game.  You could say it was challenging" but at times it just seemed clumsy.  I would often swing my ax at an enemy and get caught in a combat animation that would leave me vulnerable.  I don't know if this was intentional but it felt frustrating at times.  However
hoursPlayed: good atmosphere
helpfulPercent: interesting enemies.\nCons:  Clumsy combat
votesHelpful: somewhat stiff voice acting.\n\nI would reccommend this game.  Extra reccommendation: play it in the winter when there is snow on the ground outside  if you can.  This definetly added to my enjoyment of the game."

Sang Froid is a wonderful Indie game.

To quickly sum up this game, it's an action-based tower defense with a story tacked on to boot.  You set up your traps during the day and defend your buildings at night using traps, axe, and rifle.

The monsters come in waves and you need to set up your traps and your positioning to respond to the monsters and their path (which you can later manipulate).

Combine that with a levelling system (arguably on rails as if you survive the night, you'll level but even in failure, you can level up) in which I have yet to find a single ability which wouldn't be useful depending on playstyle. There are two playable characters which determine the difficulty of the game. Jos is a tough strong guy whereas his brother Jack is better with a gun but not as tough.

I had a really good time with this game however, there was not a great deal of play time available. You need to survive 20 nights and the story completes itself. There are plans for a Sang Froid 2 however, the company just released Conflicks on Steam and the follow up might be a while in the making.  I would also have loved perhaps some more choice in the story but for their first effort, Sang Froid was a gem.

I would give it a 8.5 out of 10 but totally worth your time and money.

Rating: 7/10
Overview: Third Person, Tower Defense
Similar Games: Orcs must Die, Iron Brigade

The Good:

+ This games focus is more about strategy and tactics. Unlike other tower defense games that throw tons of enemies at you, SangFroid gives you less enemies but makes them more powerful. In addition, the traps you place can only be used once per level making placement even more important.

+ Lots of different traps that fit specific purposes, some must be activated manually making placement even more important.

+ Lots of different weapons and accessories for combat

+ Completing levels grants you experience to upgrade skills and traps.

+ The game does a good job of slowly introducing new enemies and traps so you never feel overwhelmed. Has a good tutorial that explains many of the games mechanics.

+ soundtrack


The Average:

Melee and range combat feels lackluster.



The Bad:

- The story deals with supernatural elements but awful dialogue and lackluster voice acting bring the entire presentation down. You could easily skip all the cutscenes and still enjoy the game

- The game is poorly optimized. Even with a computer that well exceeds the max requirements, the game had terrible frame rates. Setting a lot of the graphical option to low helped fix the problem.

- long loading time when first starting game

- For a game in this genre, this game is missing a lot of modes that are practically standard in other tower defense games. For starters, you cannot replay a level without losing all your save progress after that point. After completing the game there is very little reason to go back and play the game other than hunting for achievements.


Conclusion

A great take on the tower defense genre and has a lot of potential. I would love to see a sequel that improves a lot of its flaws.

Now here's a game that caught me by surprise. Sang Froid: Tales of Werewolves is Montreal-based Artifice Studio's first title, and in spite of some general shabbiness in its presentation, they've done enough things right here that I'll be keeping an eye out for their future releases.

In Sang Froid, you play a pair of Canadian woodsman brothers, defending their sister (as well as the surrounding community) from nightly assaults by supernatural forces both Christian and Pagan in nature. Gameplay takes the form of an innovative and wonderfully executed combination of chop-em-up action, clever tower defense, and Rainbow Six-style tactical planning. Each day presents you with a chunk of storyline, and then lets you spend your limited daylight hours setting up traps on your property or logging at the local lumber yard for extra cash (which is spent on weapons, items, and some of the more dramatic and powerful trap-types). Thanks to your psychic sister, you know ahead of time what kinds of enemies will be attacking, where they'll come from, and what they intend to destroy; setting appropriate traps for each situation is crucial to survival, as you can only be in one place at a time, and your combat prowess is hardly a match for a single werewolf, let alone a pack of several.

When night falls, the assault begins and you get to see if your defenses hold up. Armed with an axe, a rifle, and whatever consumables you've brought with you, you must do everything in your power to wipe out the assaulting units. At its simplest, you can engage opponents in melee, killing off opponents that you either hadn't set traps for or which manage to survive whatever you'd prepared. While the controls are a little wobbly at times, the combat options are innovative, simple, and very intelligent. When you aren't out busting skulls, however, your job will be to run from trap to trap, activating them at the right time to deal the most damage, or letting the enemy catch your scent and then luring them to their fiery/spiky/bouldery doom. Several enemies are very resilient to your weapon attacks, and without intelligent use of traps they can be nearly unbeatable in hand-to-hand combat. You can get around this by wielding blessed or silver weaponry, but you can only carry one axe at a time, and you can't have it both ways.

I haven't had this much fun with a game in a long, long time. All the trap varieties are useful in their own way, adding interesting layers to the strategy. Plotting out the most effective and efficient layout to take out enemies is a bit intimidating at first, but quickly becomes very satisfying; there's nothing quite like knowing you've set up a fool-proof murder gauntlet and then seeing it work like a charm. Running through the woods, sneaking up on your prey as it munches on the bait you've left out; or ziplining over the forest to engage a band of demons at precisely the right moment... Each night's encounter is demanding enough to make you work for it, and all the elements involved in pulling it off are simply fun. Based purely on the gameplay, Sang Froid is an easy title to recommend.

It does have a few weaknesses though. The game suffers beneath an occasionally stuttery framerate, no-budget cutscenes, fairly basic character models, a script that's difficult to take seriously, and a voice acting cast made up of amateurs (several of whom likely have English as a second language). This is more than counterbalanced by a gorgeous musical score, an unorthodox and inventive setting that drowns out the actual writing, and the stellar gameply mentioned above. If it weren't for the fact that nobody seems to know it exists, I'd say Sang Froid has all the makings of a truly great cult classic.

Sang-Froid is one the of most disappointing games that I've played. I went into it thinking that it would be like Orcs Must Die but with werewolves, which sounded like a pretty awesome premise; instead, it turned out to be a clunky, dull action game with strategy and RPG overtones.

The worst part of the game for me is the interface. The font used was definitely picked for style rather than legibility, making it tricky to get a quick read on your ammo count. The health bar is a strange, bifurcated heart which again is not helpful for at-a-glance info. You wield two weapons, but instead of using a toggle, weapon selection is modal. You have to hold down a key to keep the rifle out. Reloading the rifle is boosted by button mashing which is an egregiously stupid mechanic. The whole town's worth of shops could have been condensed into a single screen. The fear factor UI is painfully unintuitive but works decently once explained. I think even the developers realised how bad the UI is because the tutorial is filled with videos describing in elaborate detail how everything works. When you've gotten to that step, you need to seriously rethink your design decisions.

The gameplay is where things really fell apart. It seems like most traps are one-use-only which kills the tower defence feeling for me. Because you can't rely on traps, you need to dispatch a good chunk of the enemies yourself. Unfortunately the lumberjack runs quite slowly, hits weakly and reloads his rifle in a period-correct fashion. Combat is a slow and tedious affair with the player's weakness being balanced out by the enemy's reluctance to attack. To top it off, the animations are surprisingly unsatisfying.

Calling the game an epic folktale is a bit disengenuous. The writing is 90s after-school cartoon caliber and the voice acting is pretty wooden. The animations are disappointingly stilted and exacerbate the problem; using static portraits would have been a major improvement. Worst of all, it takes itself way too seriously.

It's possible that the game gets significantly better after spending enough time on it. Unfortunately, there are plenty of other games that are better right off the bat.

SNAPSHOT
An action-RPG / tower defense game that looks like it was made by third graders. Thankfully, it plays like an 8th grade level.

OVERALL - 3.5 / 10

PROS
+ combat feels responsive
+ music is good
+ planning each level is interesting
+ relatively bug free (unless you're trying to get achievements, in which case the opposite of that)

CONS
- awful models (texturing is ok at best)
- awful voice acting
- awful writing
- way too many game mechanics overly complicates almost every portion of the game
- replaying levels *intentionally* disincentivized
- every level uses the same map for the entire game

DETAILS
Where to even begin with this one. I really wanted to like Sang-Froid, I really did. Overall I like the concept of an action-RPG + tower defense game (Orcs Must Die! does it fairly well), and the movement in the game doesn't play all that poorly, but overall it is extremely poorly executed.

Probably my biggest gripe is that combat-related gameplay itself is just a pile-on of systems that's only purposes seem to be to limit what the player can do. First there is stamina, which is a combined limit of being able to run as well as your ability to use melee combat. Melee is frustratingly bad, especially the targeting. Often times you'll be attacking an enemy that's about to die and then suddenly the game will switch targets on you and you'll be swinging at something else on the other side of the screen, leaving that low health enemy free to do whatever it wants (which 90% of the time means regen to full or cast a meteor swarm down on your face). It becomes even MORE frustrating when enemies start becoming ~90% resistant to normal damage, so unless you have a weapon the enemy is weak to you won't be doing full damage. Ranged combat requires you to reload after every single shot you take, which takes an inordinate amount of time (there's an *achievement* for reloading in under 3 seconds). You can speed up reloading slightly by mashing a button, which seems to only distract the player from how long it actually takes. Also of note for ranged combat is that it has headshot and non-headshot hitboxes that lock on" (poorly) that are infuriating more often than not. Next

reviewText: I love this game. The story is good, gameplay is good. I love the music; the gameplay and design. I bought this game over a year ago and I'm still playing it. It's challenging and fun and very rewarding as well.\n\nI'm looking forward to Tome 2

Brilliant. Combines strategy and action delightfully, and with intensity I would not have guessed. Each level works out to 2 minutes in the shops, 45 minutes of planning, a short derailment to fix a boneheaded mistake, 5 minutes of action, and a bit of exhaustion.

Plot aspects are a bit puppet-show-y, but adequate. The characters are simple, but none are worthless. It's hard to be annoyed at having to protect someone who helps you lay more traps. It is the struggle of siblings against a grave threat, with both the problem and the solution enhanced by different members of the community.

The gameplay is interesting, and absolutely astounding how much the designers give you with so few resources. From manipulating sound and scent to lure your foes into traps and ambushes, to simply running away to regroup, reload, or activate some fun toy you left for a fallback. So many sensible options to choose from... I haven't had a game stretch my tactical thinking like this in a very long time.

I raise all the thumbs I have to this game.
Picked it up cheap on a sale, definitely worth it.\n\nThe trap defense gameplay was a lot of fun and made up for the middling story

reviewText: A log cabin defense game very well done. Straight out of the North Woods. I love the art style, and the story of family trying to survive supernatural terrors is exciting. Worth your time.

Rating: 7/10
Overview: Third Person, Tower Defense
Similar Games: Orcs must Die, Iron Brigade

The Good:

+ This games focus is more about strategy and tactics. Unlike other tower defense games that throw tons of enemies at you, SangFroid gives you less enemies but makes them more powerful. In addition, the traps you place can only be used once per level making placement even more important.

+ Lots of different traps that fit specific purposes, some must be activated manually making placement even more important.

+ Lots of different weapons and accessories for combat

+ Completing levels grants you experience to upgrade skills and traps.

+ The game does a good job of slowly introducing new enemies and traps so you never feel overwhelmed. Has a good tutorial that explains many of the games mechanics.

+ soundtrack


The Average:

Melee and range combat feels lackluster.



The Bad:

- The story deals with supernatural elements but awful dialogue and lackluster voice acting bring the entire presentation down. You could easily skip all the cutscenes and still enjoy the game

- The game is poorly optimized. Even with a computer that well exceeds the max requirements, the game had terrible frame rates. Setting a lot of the graphical option to low helped fix the problem.

- long loading time when first starting game

- For a game in this genre, this game is missing a lot of modes that are practically standard in other tower defense games. For starters, you cannot replay a level without losing all your save progress after that point. After completing the game there is very little reason to go back and play the game other than hunting for achievements.


Conclusion

A great take on the tower defense genre and has a lot of potential. I would love to see a sequel that improves a lot of its flaws.
Excellent mix of TD, strategy, action and RPG. nice story.

Excellent game, so long as u enjoy strategizing and then physically implementing them. Especially enjoyable for anyone who is not flustered when their battleplan shatters upon first contact. Although, i am only half way through, I would recommend it for a light playing experience focusing on achievements, if nothing else.\n\nPS Especially liked the idea of using liqour to get short term buffs
cant run windowed mode...cant find easy way to move game to other monitor...not wasting time on it.

The game itself has so many flaws ranging from poor voice acting, story to the clunky engine and combat but there's something about it that's so endearing. If you can get past the flaws it's a pretty fun game. The soundtrack has a nice folksy vibe to it.

The game is basically a tower defence where you have about 4 buildings(later on) scattered across the map. Your objective is to protect these buildings while eliminating hostile beasts. You can reroute the beasts' paths and set traps along the way. You also have access to an axe, a rifle and a various potions and protective items. These become available for upgrade later on.

It can get hectic at times as the game is not very forgiving and you need to maximize the beasts' route into your traps given the limited resources.

Very flawed game but it grows on you if you can look past the numerous flaws. It's good enough to kill time on a lazy weekend.

Absolutely unique as well as absolutely french Canadian in a good way. lol.\n\nIts a wave defense type game, but instead of turrets you have activated traps and your ax to stop the hordes of werewolves and other creatures. Its a highly strategic game that also takes a fair amount of skill. Oh, and its rock hard. I had to do a number of mission 2-3 times to beat them on normal difficulty. Plus winning and earnings are accumulative so if you have a poor start, by the end of the game you'll have none of the best toys and have to really plan every second of the waves that'll come.

reviewText:
Brilliant. Combines strategy and action delightfully, and with intensity I would not have guessed. Each level works out to 2 minutes in the shops, 45 minutes of planning, a short derailment to fix a boneheaded mistake, 5 minutes of action, and a bit of exhaustion.

Plot aspects are a bit puppet-show-y, but adequate. The characters are simple, but none are worthless. It's hard to be annoyed at having to protect someone who helps you lay more traps. It is the struggle of siblings against a grave threat, with both the problem and the solution enhanced by different members of the community.

The gameplay is interesting, and absolutely astounding how much the designers give you with so few resources. From manipulating sound and scent to lure your foes into traps and ambushes, to simply running away to regroup, reload, or activate some fun toy you left for a fallback. So many sensible options to choose from... I haven't had a game stretch my tactical thinking like this in a very long time.

I raise all the thumbs I have to this game.

This is a very original action RPG with tower defense strategy and building elements. The storyline is a mix of Amerindian mythology and classic werewolf fiction with full voice-acting.

It's lots of fun from start to finish as you level your arsenal, character, traps and gear as the invading creatures become more and more difficult.

It's a pretty novel game overall, the closest relative I can think of would be the equally good Valkyria Chronicles.
